Comment:
[All criticism is welcomed. If there is something I missed or did wrong, let me know!]
Cicilian Defence.

[All criticism is welcomed. If there is something I missed or did wrong, let me know!]
Cicilian Defence.
White employs Bowlder Attack. I respond accordingly with e6, then later d5, clearing the center and giving me a tempo. Bc6 is played before d5 to keep the king from being exposed to Bb5+.

White employs Bowlder Attack. I respond accordingly with e6, then later d5, clearing the center and giving me a tempo. Bc6 is played before d5 to keep the king from being exposed to Bb5+.
I exchange pawns with him, clearing up the e-file and leaving his king somewhat exposed.
I exchange pawns with him, clearing up the e-file and leaving his king somewhat exposed.
He eats my pawn, but I'm not too concerned with losing it...

...since his knight isn't putting any of my pieces in danger, I'm planning on a kingside castle (O-O). The reason for this is because a check can possibly be made (Re8+) if white doesn't close up the hole. This also means white can't castle until it leaves check, stalling a good defensive position for at least a turn.
I develop my knight and white mirrors, allowing me my kingside castle as planned.
I develop my knight and white mirrors, allowing me my kingside castle as planned.
I develop my knight and white mirrors, allowing me my kingside castle as planned.
I develop my knight and white mirrors, allowing me my kingside castle as planned.
White advances his pawn, perhaps engaging the right as most of my pieces are developed leftwards. White is still open to check however...

...as such. White can't castle out of check, his only moves being Ne5, Ne3/Ne7+, Qe2, or Be3; most of which either wastes a piece, a turn, or both. The best choice here would be Be3, as it is the only move that wastes neither, and it develops his bishop.
White is almost forced to make Be3 as it is the best decision. This allows me a turn to make a tactical play...

...by placing my knight in between his pieces, I can trade it for white's knight and possibly his bishop (such as in c3 Nbxd5, Bxd5, Nxd5). White must take at least the knight trade or it will happen for him.
As
As
White takes the trade, but is reluctant to give up more material...
...I take more anyway. In its new position, my knight is now forcing his queen to develop or die.
I move my knight to safety, protected by the bishop on f6 and the rook on e8, while keeping within the king's reach. White can now be shoved into mainly defensive play with Qa5+.
I move my knight to safety, protected by the bishop on f6 and the rook on e8, while keeping within the king's reach. White can now be shoved into mainly defensive play with Qa5+.

White is once again left with limited options: b4, Qc3/Qd2, Bd2, or Nd2. b4 would simply waste a pawn, while Qc3/Qd2 would waste his queen. Bd2 isn't much better as that undevelops the e-file blockade i made him carry out earlier. Nd2 is the best move in this position.

White is once again left with limited options: b4, Qc3/Qd2, Bd2, or Nd2. b4 would simply waste a pawn, while Qc3/Qd2 would waste his queen. Bd2 isn't much better as that undevelops the e-file blockade i made him carry out earlier. Nd2 is the best move in this position.

I can no longer keep him from castling, as there are too many pieces in the way. However, Castling at this point will only leave white trapped in his own defense. I set up to exchange more pieces to clear the way.

I can no longer keep him from castling, as there are too many pieces in the way. However, Castling at this point will only leave white trapped in his own defense. I set up to exchange more pieces to clear the way.
Queen may look trapped from b4 but I don't need her for the next few exchanges.
Queen may look trapped from b4 but I don't need her for the next few exchanges.
Knights are traded, though it favors my side because it gives me the more clear playing field that I was looking for.
Knights are traded, though it favors my side because it gives me the more clear playing field that I was looking for.
White inevitably castles, though it'll prove his downfall...
...his bishop is mine.
